headline: Initial Offerings In Robins Case
abstract: LEAD: The director of the $2.4 billion trust for victims of the Dalkon Shield birth control device made by the A.H. Robins Company yesterday announced the initial settlements that would be offered by the trust.

headline: Fire Strikes Theater in Paris Showing Film on Jesus' Life
abstract: LEAD: Ten people were injured in a fire at a Parisian theater where ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' was being shown, the police said today. A police spokesman said the cause of the fire was unknown.

headline: HONEYWELL'S CHINA CONNECTION: Margaret Z. Lee; Building Bridges for Americans on China's Capitalist Road
abstract: LEAD: The taxi drivers in Shanghai last year spotted the visiting executives from Honeywell Inc. and promptly raised their rates. But they had underestimated one member of the delegation, a young woman not quite five feet tall, who exploded with rage. What bewildered them was that she was scolding them in Chinese - and in the

headline: Ex-Morgan Analyst Is Sentenced to 3-Year Prison Term
abstract: LEAD: Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr., a former junior analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company, was sentenced yesterday to three years in Federal prison for his part in an insider trading scheme that involved at least two other people.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Brooke Yachts International, Lowestoft, England, to TBWA Advertising,Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

headline: Windmill Case Guilty Plea
abstract: LEAD: A Pittsburgh man has pleaded guilty to fraud in connection with false representations made to nearly 100 people seeking windmill dealerships.

headline: Judge Finds Navistar Liable In Pension Obligations Case
abstract: LEAD: Ruling in favor of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, a Federal district judge today found that the Navistar International Transportation Corporation had sold its Wisconsin Steel division in 1977 to rid itself of the troubled unit's pension liabilities.

headline: Loan Sought For F.S.L.I.C.
abstract: LEAD: The Congressman who is likely to become chairman of the House Banking Committee next year said today that he would ask the Treasury Secretary and the chairman of the Federal Reserve to push for a $50 billion loan to the agency that rescues insolvent savings institutions.

headline: Paris Raises Rates to Bolster Franc
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of France today raised its interest rates to help bolster the franc after the French currency fell in recent days in response to a wave of strikes and a widening trade deficit.

headline: 5% Perpetual Stake Is Bought by Haft
abstract: LEAD: Robert H. Haft, who with his father has attempted takeovers of several leading retail companies, has acquired a minority interest in the Perpetual Financial Corporation, based in Washington. Mr. Haft, who purchased 5 percent of Perpetual's stock, said, ''I believe the enterprise has a bright future.

headline: Addenda
abstract: LEAD: * Wildman Advertising, Boston, has changed its name to Noble & Wecal.

headline: Manville to Sell Holophane Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Manville Corporation said it planned to sell its Holophane Lighting Systems division, based in Newark, Ohio. Alfred B. Gough, a company official, said Holophane's ''specific market niche no longer strategically fits our core businesses or future growth plans.'' Its sales should exceed $100 million this year,

headline: First Woman in Swiss Cabinet Quits; Husband Is Scrutinized
abstract: LEAD: The first woman to serve in Switzerland's Cabinet said today that she was resigning after admitting that she had advised her husband of a money-laundering investigation involving his company.

headline: 6 Concerns And Russia Near Deal
abstract: LEAD: Six of America's largest companies are on the verge of concluding an agreement with the Soviet Union that would remove a chief obstacle to doing business in Russia.

headline: Market Place; Kraft Plan Pares Margin for Error
abstract: LEAD: THE planned recapitalization at Kraft Inc. is more than just the largest such deal in history. It also looks to be the most leveraged by any standard.

headline: Daughter of Determination: Benazir Bhutto
abstract: LEAD: Benazir Bhutto, chosen today to lead the first democratically elected government in Pakistan in more than a decade, is also the first woman to become Prime Minister of a modern Islamic nation.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * John Leonardi has been promoted to executive vice president, creative director at Venet Advertising/New Jersey, Union, N.J.

headline: 2 at Shearson May Start Firm
abstract: LEAD: Thomas I. Unterberg and A. Robert Towbin, two well-known investment bankers, may leave Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to start their own firm.

headline: Savings Agency Head Sees Insurance Limits
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board contended today that Congress never intended that deposit insurance premiums cover a financial crisis like the one faced now by the savings and loan industry.

headline: Borman's Receives Offer From A.& P.
abstract: LEAD: Borman's Inc., which owns a chain of 80 grocery stores in the Detroit metropolitan area, said that it had received a $27-a-share takeover bid from the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company. Borman's owns the Farmer Jack supermarket chain, but it has been losing money recently. The offer values Borman's common stock at $75.9 million.

headline: Bio-Gas and Sun Energy Make Life Better in India
abstract: LEAD: Twenty-four-year-old Ponnulingham, like most of India's 800 million people, will never be part of the new middle class that frequents the coffee shops and health clubs of five-star hotels. Chances are he will never live in a house with electricity or running water.

headline: Smart Machines, Smart Workers
abstract: LEAD: A decade ago, robots and computerized manufacturing equipment were rapidly appearing on the assembly line as industry sought to automate the nation's factories.

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Backs Eastern on Layoffs of 4,000
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Airlines won another victory yesterday in its fight to cut its work force and operations when a Federal appeals court upheld its right to lay off 4,000 employees.

headline: Gorbachev's Shake-Up: Logical and Apparently Urgent
abstract: LEAD: The shakeup in the Soviet leadership this week, although unexpected in its timing and breadth, represents a logical step in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's effort to restructure the political system and flows from the other initiatives he has taken to reshape the country since assuming power in March 1985.

headline: Simple and Safe Continues to Sell Best
abstract: LEAD: Fourteen months after the stock market crash, individual investors overwhelmingly prefer investments that they believe are simple, safe and predictable, financial executives say. But there is one big exception: Many investors are snapping up shares of ''junk bond'' funds - apparently feeling the high returns are worth the risks.

headline: More Revlon for Tarlow
abstract: LEAD: Revlon Inc. has been good to Richard J. Tarlow. First its Max Factor division drew him out of retirement on Shelter Island to start up Tarlow Advertising. Then it gave him the Jean Nate and Jontue accounts. Now the cosmetics company's Almay subsidiary has handed him a group of products to advertise.

headline: Libya to Return a Body
abstract: LEAD: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, is willing to return the body of an American pilot killed in the 1986 air raid on Libya, the official Libyan press agency reported today. The body of Capt. Paul F. Lorence is to be given to his family ''through the Pope,'' said the agency.

headline: 12 Chilean Generals Retired, Including Pinochet's Deputy
abstract: LEAD: President Augusto Pinochet reorganized the highest ranks of his army today, sending a dozen generals into retirement.
