headline: Italy Seizes Lebanese Who May Have Hostage Role
abstract: LEAD: The police in Milan said today that they had arrested a Lebanese woman who arrived from Beirut carrying three letters reportedly written by Americans held hostage in Lebanon. The woman also reportedly had at least two photographs of the American hostages.

headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
abstract: LEAD: A WORD-PROCESSING program may become available in the next decade that may be unlike anything sold today. For starters, this one would come on a compact disk. You would insert it into the ''B'' drive of your personal computer, which holds a half-height compact disk read-only memory player, known as a CD-ROM.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Children's Ad Group Forms Business Panel
abstract: LEAD: The Children's Advertising Review Unit, the division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus that studies and, with industry compliance, regulates ads directed at children, has announced the formation of a business advisory committee.

headline: CHINA REINING IN ECONOMY'S SHIFT TO A FREE MARKET
abstract: LEAD: The Chinese Government, in an effort to reassert control over the country's economy, has imposed a series of stringent measures in the last week intended to reduce sharply the role of the free market and local decision-making in economic affairs.

headline: Postal Fraud Case Charges
abstract: LEAD: Two top executives of Recognition Equipment Inc., a manufacturer of information processing equipment that has been under investigation for two and a half years by the United States Attorney's office in connection with a Postal Service bribery scheme, are expected to be indicted by Federal grand juries in Washington this week, the company said on

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Coca-Cola Enterprises, Atlanta, named James M. Stevens to take responsibility for its West Group, based in Los Angeles, replacing Larry Smith, who has resigned. Replacing Mr. Stevens as head of the North Group, Columbia, Md., is T. Michael Taschler.

headline: South African Family Mourns Son Who 'Disappeared'
abstract: LEAD: A gentle man wearing his best Sunday suit and the look of personal tragedy, Matome Bopape wondered today about the whereabouts of his oldest son, Stanza.

headline: 3.6% Inflation in Europe
abstract: LEAD: Inflation in the European Community stood at 3.6 percent in August, unchanged from a year ago but up slightly from July, a report released today said. The community's statistical agency, Eurostat, said the consumer price index rose 3.4 percent in July. It said the average inflation rate for the first six months of the year was 2.6 percent.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Investment Firm Sees Benefits in Small Size
abstract: LEAD: In reaction to the news that the Carlyle Group L.P. is offering to buy Fairchild Industries Inc. for $15.50 a share, or $220 million, some financial people are asking how a small, Washington-based investment firm with no Wall Street credentials can expect to make it in the rough-and-tumble world of leveraged buyouts?

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campaign Rhetoric And Science Fiction
abstract: LEAD: The Presidential campaign is over but some of its most memorable words live on, appropriately enough, in an advertisement for the new John Carpenter film, ''They Live.''

headline: Trump Shuttle Head Delighted With Post
abstract: LEAD: Bruce R. Nobles takes perhaps a special delight in being chosen to head the East Coast air shuttle operation purchased yesterday by Donald J. Trump from the Texas Air Corporation. It was only a few years ago that Mr. Nobles was president and chief operating officer of the Pan Am shuttle, a subsidiary of the Pan American

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * A. David Jones, a senior vice president at BBDO, Detroit, has been promoted to senior management representative.

headline: Macmillan and Maxwell Sell Four Units to Kohlberg
abstract: LEAD: Macmillan Inc. and the Maxwell Communications Corporation yesterday announced the sale of four subsidiaries for about $400 million, just a month Macmillan was acquired for $2.5 billion by Robert Maxwell, the British publisher .

headline: Teheran Suspends P.O.W. Trade With Baghdad
abstract: LEAD: Iran announced today that it was suspending the exchange of sick and wounded prisoners of war with Iraq because the exchange was uneven.

headline: Marines in Panama Fired On
abstract: LEAD: United States Marine guards at an Air Force base in Panama exchanged sporadic gunfire with unidentified intruders for almost two hours, but no injuries or casualties were reported, the Defense Department said today. The incident, the fourth such in a month, occurred Monday night on the southern boundary of a petroleum tank area at Howard Air Force Base.

headline: McDonnell Douglas Wins Swiss Contract
abstract: LEAD: Switzerland's military chief today awarded the McDonnell Douglas Corporation a $1.8 billion contract to build 34 F/A-18 Hornets for the Swiss armed forces, whose fleet consists of 30-year-old French-made Mirage fighters.

headline: After Gains, Poland Is Given Its First World Bank Loan
abstract: LEAD: Poland has recently achieved limited successes in revamping its troubled economy, American and international economic officials say, despite the labor unrest of August and continuing tensions between the Solidarity labor movement and the Government in Warsaw.

abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and officials of many member nations have challenged the legality of the American decision to deny a visa to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, who had been invited to address the General Assembly. headline: RJR Nabisco Explains Its Choice
abstract: LEAD: The RJR Nabisco board indicated yesterday that fear of disrupting the bidding process was among the many reasons it chose a deal with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company over a management group's ''substantially equivalent'' offer.

headline: Holiday Slows Bond Activity
abstract: LEAD: Activity in the Treasury bond market was virtually nonexistent yesterday, with the United States market closed for Columbus Day. Japanese financial markets were also closed.

headline: Savings Bonds At 7.35% Rate
abstract: LEAD: United States savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 7.35 percent in the next six months, the highest return since early 1986, the Treasury Department said today.

headline: Platform Problem Aborts Launching of First Soviet Shuttle Mission
abstract: LEAD: The first launching of the Soviet space shuttle was aborted today, 51 seconds before the scheduled liftoff, when an emergency evacuation platform failed to separate from the rocket body and computer sensors shut down the launching, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported.

abstract: LEAD: Three more names will be added to the Advertising Hall of Fame. They are Sidney R. Goldstein, who served as vice president of advertising at Procter & Gamble, and Ray A.

headline: From Levine Arrest to Drexel Settlement
abstract: LEAD:  MAY 12, 1986: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses Dennis B. Levine of Drexel Burnham Lambert of making $12.6 million in illegal trading on inside information since 1980. The next day Mr. Levine is arrested in New York and charged with obstructing justice and attempting to destroy records.

headline: Pretoria Agrees to Namibia-Angola Peace Accord
abstract: LEAD: South Africa announced tonight that it had formally accepted the terms of a peace accord for southwestern Africa, reached after months of negotiations with Cuba and Angola under American mediation.

headline: Soviets Urge Nations to Provide a U.N. Army
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has suggested that countries routinely earmark some of their armed forces for United Nations peacekeeping duties, effectively giving the United Nations an army of its own.

headline: Leveling Taxes . . .
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor: What Herbert Stein neglected to say in ''Tax the Rich, They Consume Too Much'' (Business Forum, Oct. 23) is that a flexible and fair taxation system is beneficial to both taxpayers and to the American economy.

headline: Pro Bono
abstract: LEAD: * Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, a unit of Grey Advertising, has completed print and television ads for the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York.

headline: Cocoa Talks Are Delayed
abstract: LEAD: Twelve cocoa-producing countries have postponed a two-day summit meeting in which they had planned to discuss ways to support slumping prices.

headline: Apple Computer Official To Take 5-Month Leave
abstract: LEAD: Deborah A. Coleman, the former manufacturing chief who rose to become the chief financial officer and vice president of Apple Computer Inc., said yesterday that she would take a five-month leave of absence because of health and personal considerations.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Blue Cross Account To BBDO Los Angeles
abstract: LEAD: Blue Cross of California in Woodland Hills has tapped BBDO Los Angeles to handle its advertising. The budget is $8 million. Also vying for the business were Grey Advertising, San Francisco, and the incumbent, Mojo San Francisco, which handled the account for 15 years.

headline: Syrian Troops in Beirut Move to Curb Fighting
abstract: LEAD: Rival Shiite Muslim militias fought fierce battles in mainly Muslim West Beirut again today before Syrian troops intervened to check the violence.

headline: German Resigns In Speech Furor
abstract: LEAD: The Speaker of the West German Parliament, Philipp Jenninger, resigned yesterday after setting off a political storm with a Kristallnacht anniversary speech in which he tried to show how Germans were taken in by Hitler.

headline: Shift at Control Data Spurs a Resignation
abstract: LEAD: The Control Data Corporation yesterday named a new president and vice chairman and announced that another top executive would leave in a management realignment.

headline: Soviets Said to Deploy Missiles in Kabul
abstract: LEAD: The United States accused the Soviet Union today of deploying advanced missiles in Kabul, the Afghan capital, and said they posed a threat to Pakistan.

headline: Japan Says U.S. Salvos Almost Hit Ship
abstract: LEAD: A United States Navy destroyer far from its target practice area fired a series of shells on Wednesday that narrowly missed a Japanese patrol boat, Government officials said Friday.

headline: 10 Jets to Morocco
abstract: LEAD: Morocco's national carrier, Royal Air Maroc, said it would buy 10 jets from the Boeing Company for $450 million. Air Maroc said that, besides the 737-400's and 737-500's that it had ordered, it was taking options on 10 more planes. The carrier, which now has two 747's in a fleet of 22 aircraft, has annual revenues of about $350 million and employs 4,800 people in 30 countries.

headline: Realty Concern's Stake in Formica
abstract: LEAD: Great American Realty Inc., a real estate concern based in Chicago, said it had acquired a 9.9 percent stake in the Formica Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Great American also said it was seeking Federal antitrust clearance to raise its stake in the decorative surfacing products manufacturer to 15 percent.

headline: 'Fed Up' Likud Hints Again at Deal With Rightists
abstract: LEAD: Israel's political leaders continued to flounder today in their nearly seven-week effort to form a new government.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * American Greetings Corp., Cleveland, a maker of greeting cards, promoted Edward Fruchtenbaum and James R. Van Arsdale to senior vice presidents, of marketing and operations, respectively.

abstract: LEAD: The jeweled Christian Lacroix T-shirt on the cover of the new issue of Vogue costs at least $10,000. headline: Forstmann Declines to Bid on RJR Nabisco
abstract: LEAD: The field of bidders for RJR Nabisco Inc. narrowed yesterday when an investment group led by Forstmann Little & Company declined to enter the corporate world's largest-ever auction.

headline: Hurricane Hits Nicaragua; Toll for Week Is Now 65
abstract: LEAD: With powerful winds and torrential rains, Hurricane Joan smashed across Nicaragua's Caribbean coast today, splintering houses and unleashing floods and mud slides across a wide swath of Central America.

headline: Strikers at Gdansk Shipyard Can Stay On, Managers Rule
abstract: LEAD: Shipyard workers who staged a one-day strike in Gdansk can keep their jobs for now, the yard's management announced today. State-run information media reported earlier that the strikers had been dismissed.

headline: 34 Slain in Colombia As Rebels Open Fire In Town, Police Say
abstract: LEAD: Thirty-four civilians were killed and 31 wounded when guerrillas descended on the northern Colombian town of Segovia on Friday night, firing on anything that moved, the military authorities said today.

headline: CoastAmerica Tie To American Hoist
abstract: LEAD: The CoastAmerica Corporation, a hardware retailer, agreed to be acquired by the American Hoist and Derrick Company in a $110 million deal. The merger will create the fifth-largest United States hardware distribution business, with more than over $800 million in annual sales.

headline: The Economic Pace Slows Down a Bit
abstract: LEAD: The economy's pace slackened to an annual growth rate of 2.2 percent in the third quarter. The gain in gross national product was the smallest in nearly two years and came after growth of 3 percent and 3.4 percent in the immediately preceding quarters. The blame for the decline fell on the summer drought and a weaker trade performance.

headline: Drexel Appeal on Judge Is Dismissed
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court yesterday dismissed a challenge brought by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to the impartiality of a district judge hearing the Government's securities fraud action.

headline: FIGHTING INTENSE FOR AFGHAN CITIES
abstract: LEAD: Fighting between the Afghan guerrillas and soldiers of the Soviet-backed Afghan Government has intensified in the last month, particularly in provinces bordering Pakistan where some of the heaviest fighting of the war is under way, Western diplomats in Islamabad say.

headline: Quebec Offers a Compromise in 'Poster War'
abstract: LEAD: The government of predominantly French-speaking Quebec Province announced a new compromise today in its 10-year-old ''poster war.'' It will continue to outlaw signs not in French on the streets, but it will allow them inside buildings.

headline: Bhutto Wins Vote of Confidence
abstract: LEAD: Acting President Ghulam Ishaq Khan easily won a five-year presidential term today and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto scored a victory in her first parliamentary vote of confidence.

headline: Pepperell Setback On Farley Offer
abstract: LEAD: A Federal court in Atlanta refused to stay a $1.3 billion bid by Farley Inc. for West Point-Pepperell Inc. The Chicago-based Farley, which makes BVD underwear, began its $48-a-share bid for the textile maker, based in West Point, Ga., last month. Pepperell contended that Farley could not finance its bid because its adviser, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., was ineligible.

headline: Stocks Prices Tumble With Dow Off 24.35
abstract: LEAD: The stock market fell sharply yesterday, pulled down in part by takeover stocks that were sold off amid concerns about buyout financing.

headline: European Community Gives Limited Support to Steps by the P.L.O.
abstract: LEAD: The European Community declared today that the statements by the Palestine National Council last week included ''positive steps towards the peaceful settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.'' But the Western Europeans stopped well short of approving the creation of an independent Palestinian state.

headline: Khartoum Journal; A Further Lesson in the Politics of Swollen Bellies
abstract: LEAD: It has been eight months since the last food train arrived in the besieged town of Aweil, a once-fertile place where tens of thousands of people have been trapped by war and famine.

headline: 22 Soldiers and 100 Rebels Reportedly Die in Peru Clash
abstract: LEAD: Peruvian Army helicopters and elite anti-guerrilla troops chased a rebel column deep into the jungle today, the military said. The rebel column was withdrawing after a fierce battle on Tuesday in which 100 rebels and 22 soldiers were killed, army officials said.

headline: France Plans Meeting on Chemical Weapons
abstract: LEAD: France announced today that it would hold an international conference intended to stiffen and extend a 1925 convention banning the use of chemical and biological weapons.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Aerospace Co., Morris Township, N.J., a unit of Allied-Signal Inc., announced that William C. Purple, president of its Defense Systems Co. and an executive vice president of the parent company, will retire at the end of the year.

headline: Bonds Stage Rally Led by Futures Trading
abstract: LEAD: A brief but sharp rally yesterday in Chicago's Treasury bond futures market caused prices to move up in the cash market. Dealers in Chicago and New York said the advance reflected largely technical factors, and trading remained extremely thin in the pre-holiday atmosphere.

headline: Bond Prices Off Sharply On Job Data
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury bond market was sent reeling yesterday by the Commerce Department's report of an unexpectedly sharp rise in the nation's employment in October.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Airbus Industrie signed a $350 million agreement to supply three wide-bodied A300-600R planes to the United Arab Emirates carrier, Emirates Airlines.

headline: Swindon Journal; The Thinker's Pub, With a Resident Philosopher
abstract: LEAD: In this former railway town, where coal smoke spirals from chimneys and mingles with autumn's chill, the convivial regulars at the Beehive Pub sometimes order another round over discussions of Plato, the nature of the universe and, well, just what it all means.

headline: CANADA VOTE RACE SEEMS TO TIGHTEN
abstract: LEAD: Despite widespread expectations that the governing Progressive Conservatives would be easily returned to power in Canada, the general election campaign appears to have suddenly tightened because of voter anxieties over the free-trade pact with the United States.

headline: Testing 'Smart' Roads To Avoid Traffic Jams
abstract: LEAD: Americans are now spending more than 1.6 billion hours a year waiting in traffic jams, a number that the Federal Highway Administration expects to grow to 8.1 billion hours by the year 2005. Most traffic experts think it is unlikely that enough new highways can be built to alleviate the problem.

headline: PSYCHIATRY TALKS PLANNED IN RUSSIA
abstract: LEAD: American and Soviet negotiators in Moscow will try to work out the ground rules next week for a planned visit by American psychiatrists to Soviet mental hospitals, American specialists said today.

headline: Pretoria Retreats on Measure To Enforce Segregation Law
abstract: LEAD: President P. W. Botha has shelved legislation that would have increased financial penalties on blacks and other nonwhite South Africans living in residential areas that are legally reserved for whites.

headline: Boeing Jet Order
abstract: LEAD: America West Airlines Inc. ordered 15 of Boeing's 737-300 jetliners and 10 of the 757 commercial jets in a deal worth about $800 million. The carrier, based in Phoenix, also took options for 10 more 737-300's and 15 other 757's. The airline will receive the initial 25 planes over a three-year period beginning in 1992.

headline: Treasury Notes and Bonds Climb
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher again yesterday, helped by a dip in oil prices and the purchase of an estimated $3 billion to $4 billion in securities by the Federal Reserve.

headline: Saving Unit's Sale in Jersey
abstract: LEAD: First Nationwide Bank, the Ford Motor Company's savings and loan subsidiary, announced yesterday that it was acquiring a savings institution in New Jersey with $1.2 billion in assets. The move signals further inroads into the competitive New York-New Jersey region by First Nationwide, which is based in San Francisco.

headline: Chinese and Russians Talk About Cambodia
abstract: LEAD: China's Foreign Minister opened the first working visit to Moscow by a senior Chinese official in more than 30 years today with intensive talks about the Soviet-supported presence of Vietnamese troops in Cambodia.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., a maker of portable electric tools, said William E. Stevens, executive vice president, planned to resign at the end of this month after assisting the company through its turnaround period, which is virtually completed. It added that he would pursue personal business interests.

headline: Excerpts From Arafat's Address to General Assembly Offering Peace Plan
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the address today by Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, to the United Nations General Assembly. The text, translated from the Arabic, was provided by the P.L.O.

headline: Now in Season: 500-Page Guides to Those Simplified Tax Rules
abstract: LEAD: Many books left over from the holidays will soon be taken off the shelves of bookstores and returned to their publishers for credit. But the selling season is just beginning for a record number of tax preparation guidebooks, some of them bigger and bulkier than ever.

headline: Trail of Bomb on Pan Am Jet Is Said to Lead to Frankfurt; New Threat Received
abstract: LEAD: An unidentified caller claiming to represent a pro-Iranian group today again took responsibility for the Pan Am bombing and threatened unspecified further action against the United States.

headline: Opinion Is Sought in Drexel Case
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan yesterday asked that the Securities and Exchange Commission give its opinion about conflict of interest charges leveled against a judge in the securities fraud case against Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: Algeria Leader Rejects A Multiparty System
abstract: LEAD: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria today ruled out a multiparty system as part of the political changes he has proposed after the riots that shook the country this month.

headline: Savings Industry Losses Fell 60% in 3d Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Losses in the savings and loan industry declined by 60 percent in the third quarter, reflecting the rescue of many insolvent institutions by the Government, M. Danny Wall, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.

headline: Barcelona Journal; Madrid? Who'd Want to Get There From Here?
abstract: LEAD: Catalonia at its most prickly is once again at the leading edge of Spanish affairs.

headline: Loan Expert to Lead Fidelity in Philadelphia
abstract: LEAD: Leslie E. Goodman has taken on a sensitive job in the regional banking industry as chairman and chief executive of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia.

headline: Exchanges Begin Fight Over Proposed Product
abstract: LEAD: A legal battle is brewing between some of the nation's stock and and futures exchanges over a recently proposed trading instrument, and some officials believe the dispute could result in a jurisdictional fight among Federal regulators.

headline: Insider Inquiry in Paris Set
abstract: LEAD: The French stock market watchdog, La Commission des Operations de Bourse, has begun an inquiry into possible insider trading activity in the days before the takeover of Triangle Industries by the French metal conglomerate Pechiney S.A. in November.

headline: Spanish Officials Meet With Labor Leaders
abstract: LEAD: It took a bitter one-day strike that paralyzed the country and a plea from King Juan Carlos before Government officials and leaders of the two largest labor organizations sat down and talked to each other.

headline: World Bank Loan to Nigeria
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank said today that its board had approved a $500 million loan to help Nigeria reshape its economy and reduce its dependence on oil exports.

headline: INVESTING; Will Boeing Add East to West?
abstract: LEAD: WHEN LOT, Poland's national airline, recently ordered three Boeing 767 passenger jets, the news was not the size of the deal. At $220 million, it was small potatoes for Boeing, which may top $17 billion in sales this year.

headline: Patents; Controversial Motor to Get New Hearing
abstract: LEAD: Joseph W. Newman, who has been battling the Patent and Trademark Office for nine years in defense of what critics deride as a perpetual motion machine, takes his case to the nation's top patent court on Tuesday.

abstract: LEAD: The Stouffer Hotel Company, which is based in Solon, Ohio, acquired the Stanford Court, one of the most luxurious hotels in San Francisco. The 402-room hotel was purchased from the Royal Stanford Hotel Company, a California limited partnership, for an undisclosed amount. It is Stouffer's first hotel in San Francisco and its second in

headline: Egypt Puts Nasser Kin and 17 Others on Trial
abstract: LEAD: To the chanting of anti-Israeli slogans, 20 Egyptians, including members of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser's family, went on trial here today on charges of assassinating Israeli diplomats, wounding others and attacking United States Embassy officials.

headline: Statement by Arafat On Peace in Mideast
abstract: LEAD: Following is a transcript of the statement made by Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, at a news conference today, as recorded by Reuters:

headline: First Recipient Of Award Named
abstract: LEAD: The Association of National Advertisers yesterday named Robert Haynes, the recently retired director of creative services for the General Foods Corporation, the first recipient of its Robert V. Goldstein Award for distinguished service as an Advertising Council campaign director.

headline: U.N. Condemns Israel's Policy on Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: The General Assembly voted 130 to 2 today to condemn Israel for its suppression of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. It said repressive Israeli actions there violate the Palestinians' human rights.

headline: English-Made Nissans At Center of Trade Fight
abstract: LEAD: Angry Japanese and British officials say foreign investors will be scared away from Europe unless France and Italy ease tough regulations that treat English-made Nissans as Japanese cars, subjecting them to strict import quotas. The British also fear that jobs will be lost.

headline: Nicaragua to Continue Truce
abstract: LEAD: The Government extended a seven-month truce with rebels today until the end of November, despite what it called continued aggression by the rebels, known as contras, and their sponsors in the United States. A Government said the decision to prolong the truce provided a contrast to the Reagan Administration's policies.

headline: Soviet Bank For Projects
abstract: LEAD: A new Soviet bank has been created to finance high-risk scientific and engineering projects, the newspaper Pravda said last week.

headline: Notes and Bonds Little Changed
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in very light trading yesterday, a session that market participants said was likely to prove typical for the balance of this holiday-shortened week.

headline: Parting Shot By President Of Four A's
abstract: LEAD: IN his 10 years at the helm of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, Leonard Sarver Matthews has rarely equivocated. He has called comparative advertising a ''wart,'' speculative creative work by agencies pitching an account a ''malignancy,'' a major consultant a ''quisling.'' The 756 member agencies of the Four

headline: Ex-Lehman Chairman Hears Wall St.'s Call
abstract: LEAD: Lewis L. Glucksman, who was chairman and chief executive of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. until its purchase by Shearson/American Express Inc. four years ago, said yesterday that he expected to be back on Wall Street very soon.

headline: Trade Paperbacks Gaining In Role of a Happy Medium
abstract: LEAD: WHEN inflation and declining sales forced book publishers against the financial wall in the early 1980's, many of them sought refuge in trade paperback books. Bigger than the rack-sized mass-market paperbacks and only about half the price of hardcovers, they seemed a perfect solution because of their portability and affordability.

headline: 'Leak' Is an Issue in Aid Scandal
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee asked the Reagan Administration today to investigate whether Administration officials had leaked classified papers to the authors of a newspaper article describing corruption in a secret United States program to aid Cambodian rebels.

headline: Objections to A.T.&T. Sales Plan Likely
abstract: LEAD: Competitors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are likely to object to its proposals to provide promotional discounts for business customers, communiciations industry analysts said yesterday.

headline: Palestinians See Uprising Fueled by Israel Right
abstract: LEAD: Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories predicted today that the strong showing of right-wing parties in the election would feed the Arab uprising.

headline: Oil Experts See No Rebound Until OPEC Limits Output
abstract: LEAD: The nation's oil production industry will remain in a prolonged slump until the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries regains control of the market and increases prices, industry experts said yesterday.

headline: Article 615288 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: A West German trading group, Kloeckner & Company, which announced up to $380 million in oil trading losses earlier this month, said today that the country's largest bank would give it 400 million West German marks ($225 million) to help it recover.

headline: 2 Write-Offs Are Planned
abstract: LEAD: The Washington Post Company and Knight-Ridder Inc. both announced yesterday that they would take multimillion-dollar charges against their fourth-quarter earnings.

headline: Bank Board to Alter Its Evaluation Method
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, beset by criticism that it is the weakest of the agencies regulating financial institutions, has overhauled its system for examining savings and loan institutions.

headline: Tax Watch; 4th-Quarter Plans To Reduce Taxes
abstract: LEAD: IN the final quarter of the year, the thoughts of many investors turn to taxes and how to avoid them. While the Tax Reform Act of 1986 did its best to dash hopes of avoidance, there are still techniques available to soften the tax bite.

headline: FROM PRETORIA, HOPEFUL SIGNALS
abstract: LEAD: While South Africa says publicly that it is still studying the detailed plan for regional peace in southern Africa that Angola and Cuba approved Friday, there were indications today that the Pretoria Government was likely to give its assent.

headline: The G. Gordon Liddy Story Continues With Chapter 11
abstract: LEAD: A Miami-based security company co-founded by G. Gordon Liddy, the convicted Watergate burglar who became a television and movie villain, has sought protection from its creditors under the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: Hand-Held TV/VCR Unit: Breakthrough or a Gimmick?
abstract: LEAD: For the last two months, passengers boarding the Hokutosei, a 16-hour overnight express train from Tokyo to Sapporo, Japan, have been given a new toy just for the ride: a combination television set and videocassette recorder, shrunk to the size of a tall paperback book.

headline: Namibia and Angola: A Tangled Past
abstract: LEAD:  1884The Germans colonize South-West Africa, a mineral-producing and mostly desert territory with a long Atlantic coastline.  1915South Africa invades; Germany gives up the territory.  1920The League of Nations gives South Africa a mandate to administer the territory.  1946A United Nations trusteeship replaces the mandate; South Africa rejects the change.

headline: Efforts Begin to Rebuild Nabisco's Morale
abstract: LEAD: Henry R. Kravis and another partner of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company flew to RJR Nabisco Inc.'s headquarters in Atlanta yesterday to begin rebuilding morale at the company that their investor group agreed to purchase earlier this week for $24.88 billion.

headline: IC's Rail Spinoff Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The Interstate Commerce Commission ruled that IC Industries' proposed spinoff of its Illinois Central Railroad Company was not within its jurisdiction. A spokesman for IC Industries, a Chicago-based consumer products company, said that the ruling cleared the way for a spinoff of the railroad, but an I.C.C.

headline: Citicorp's Ambac Unit Completing Transition
abstract: LEAD: H. Russell Fraser, one of the pioneers in the business of insuring municipal bonds, is stepping down as president and chief executive of Ambac Inc., completing a transition that began when Citicorp bought the company three years ago.

headline: U.S. Retaliates for Iraqi Expulsion Of Diplomat by Replying in Kind
abstract: LEAD: Iraq has expelled an American diplomat stationed in Baghdad for having contacts with Iraq's Kurdish minority, and the United States retaliated today by expelling an Iraqi diplomat from Washington, the State Department said.

headline: AIRLINES DROPPING KEY DISCOUNT FARE OVER MOST ROUTES
abstract: LEAD: Most major airlines plan to sharply curtail a popular discount fare starting next Tuesday as part of a broad overhaul of the discount fare programs that have saved travelers hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Shultz Vigorous in Defending Decision Denying Arafat Visit
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, under foreign pressure to reverse himself, stood firm today and vigorously defended his decision denying a visa to Yasir Arafat.

headline: Treasury Prices Post Sharp Rise
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds staged their biggest one-day rally in more than three months yesterday on the heels of strong foreign buying, favorable technical factors and reports that Mikhail S. Gorbachev may propose a sharp reduction in Soviet military forces.

headline: Fugitive Greek Banker Is Arrested by the F.B.I.
abstract: LEAD: A fugitive Greek banker, indicted in a $300 million scandal that has shaken the Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, has been arrested, the F.B.I. said today.

headline: Sakharov and Teller Debate 'Star Wars'
abstract: LEAD: The fathers of the Soviet and American hydrogen bomb projects met for the first time tonight and publicly aired their differences over President Reagan's Strategic Defense Inititiative.

headline: Net Doubles At Primerica
abstract: LEAD: The Primerica Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings had more than doubled, largely beause of the sales of two subsidiaries and the redemption of some debentures.

abstract: LEAD: Edward A. Brennan, the man who put the world's tallest building on the auction block last week, is attempting to redefine Sears, Roebuck & Company for its 526,000 employees, 328,000 shareholders, 10,000 suppliers, and 70 million household customers.

headline: Prospects; Deregulation Plus Five
abstract: LEAD: Five years ago, a Federal District Court ordered the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's telephone monopoly. While some facets of the business have seen competition increase, critics contend that in others, costs have risen and service has deteriorated. The industry remains in flux, however, as companies move in and out of businesses.

abstract: LEAD: The GTE Corporation said today that it had filed a libel and slander suit against Home Shopping Network Inc. in response to a $1.5 billion suit filed by the television shopping network in 1987 over problems with its GTE telephone system. In its suit, filed in Pinellas

abstract: LEAD: The TLC Group, the investment group headed by the New York financier Reginald F. Lewis, is holding talks with three parties interested in acquiring the Beatrice International Company's 75 percent stake in a Hong Kong food operation. Among the suitors are Nestle S.A., the Swiss food company, and two other leading international food concerns, parties close to the talks said.

abstract: LEAD: Eugene Patterson, 65 years old, retired today as chief executive of the Times Publishing Company of St. Petersburg and was succeeded by Andrew Barnes, editor and president. headline: Criminal Indictments Are Closer on Drexel
abstract: LEAD: The two-year criminal investigation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. may be nearing a turning point soon with the indictments of the firm and several employees, including a senior executive, Michael R. Milken, people involved in the case said yesterday.

headline: Big Euramerica Harvest From a Little Town
abstract: LEAD: In Pennsylvania Dutch country, the town of New Holland has delivered two completely unrelated accounts to Euramerica Advertising, an Ogilvy Group subsidiary.

headline: Navy Removes Captain Over Japan Shelling
abstract: LEAD: The captain of a United States Navy destroyer that fired a volley of shells near a Japanese patrol boat 12 days ago, touching off a sharp protest from Japan, has been relieved of his command, Navy officials said today.

headline: Raisa Gorbachev Gets Place of Honor
abstract: LEAD: Who should be seated to the right of Marcela Perez de Cuellar, wife of the Secretary General of the United Nations, at her luncheon tomorrow? Raisa Gorbachev or Nancy Reagan? United Nations protocol is avoiding the guest-of-honor issue by describing the event as ''a luncheon on the occasion of the visit of Mrs.

headline: Sakharov Warns of Perils in New Soviet Setup
abstract: LEAD: Reflecting what appears to be the view of many Soviet intellectuals, Andrei D. Sakharov warned today that planned changes in the Soviet political system would give Mikhail S. Gorbachev a dangerous monopoly of power.

headline: Israeli Concern Seeks State Bailout
abstract: LEAD: Executives of Koor Industries, Israel's largest industrial conglomerate, and officials of its creditor banks are increasing efforts to obtain a Government bailout to keep the heavily indebted company from foundering. But Israeli officials have not publicly said they would engage in a bailout.

headline: In Oslo, Blessings for 733 Who Kept the Peace
abstract: LEAD: The 733 United Nations soldiers who have died keeping the peace in troubled places were remembered today in the ancient cathedral of this Scandinavian capital.

headline: Baldrige Quality Awards
abstract: LEAD: The Commerce Department today named the first three winners of the Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Awards. They are Motorola Inc., the commercial nuclear fuel division of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and Globe Metallurgical Inc. The awards are named for the Secretary of Commerce who was killed in a horseback riding accident last year.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Cannon Group Inc., Los Angeles, a film company, said it would build about 30 multiscreen movie theaters in Britain in the next five years.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 451 money market mutual funds increased $305.4 million, to $267.46 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 125 institutional funds were down $490.3 million, to $69.07 billion. Assets of the 223 general-purpose funds were down $80.80 million, to $85.04 billion.

headline: Swedish Farm Animals Get a Bill of Rights
abstract: LEAD: The Swedish welfare state, long renowned for its generosity and scope, is extending its reach into a new frontier: the barnyard.

headline: Hebrew Teaching in Russia Seen as Means to Win West
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet decision to end a ban on the teaching of Hebrew and to allow the establishment of a Jewish cultural center is aimed at ''getting the Jewish question off the East-West negotiating table,'' the president of the World Jewish Congress said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Rochelle Newman has been named vice chairman of Font & Vaamonde, a Grey Advertising affiliate that markets to the Hispanic community.

headline: Creating a Brand Image For Eggs
abstract: LEAD: IN advertising, there's no question that the chicken came before the egg.

headline: In Nicaragua's Press, a Softer Voice
abstract: LEAD: A group of young journalists, determined to break with Nicaragua's tradition of strident and politicized reporting, has launched a new weekly newspaper pledged to independence and balance, but with an unabashed anti-Sandinista tint.

headline: Popeye's Owner Makes Bid For Church's Fried Chicken
abstract: LEAD: A. Copeland Enterprises Inc., owner of Popeye's Famous Fried Chicken, said yesterday that it was offering to buy Church's Fried Chicken Inc. for $8 a share, or a total of $295.7 million.

headline: Dow's Close Is 2d Highest Since Crash
abstract: LEAD: Stocks rallied to close moderately higher yesterday, led by strength in blue-chip issues, as the Dow Jones industrial average finished just short of its highest close in more than a year.

headline: Oil Prices Down on Fears OPEC Will Not Cut Output
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil prices fell yesterday, amid fears that the production quota recently adopted by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would not hold.

headline: Iraqi Orders Trial of Son for Killing
abstract: CAIRO--President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today ordered his eldest son investigated and tried for the killing of a presidential guard, the Baghdad radio reported.

headline: Jetliner Carrying 258 to U.S. Crashes in Scottish Town
abstract: LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A Pan Am Boeing 747 on a flight from London to New York with 258 people aboard crashed tonight in a southern Scottish village, British military authorities reported. The airline said it knew of no survivors.

headline: U.S. Ambassador in Tunisia Makes Fast P.L.O. Contact
abstract: LEAD: The diplomat designated as the sole American liaison with the Palestine Liberation Organization moved swiftly today to establish contact with the group and schedule formal talks.

headline: In U.S., Low-Key Calls for a Yes Vote in Canada
abstract: LEAD: Canadian rejection of the free-trade agreement with the United States would derail years of efforts by Washington and Ottawa to achieve much closer economic and political cooperation at a time the European Community is moving to form a single, unified market.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Andover Bancorp, Andover, Mass., a bank holding company, and its subsidiary Andover Savings Bank promoted Robert M. Henderson to the new post of chairman and chief executive. Both concerns also promoted his son, Robert A. Henderson, to executive vice president. James E. McCobb Jr., chief financial officer of Andover Bancorp, added the posts of president and chief operating officer.

abstract: LEAD: The Boston Water and Sewer Commission has tentatively priced $57.9 million in general revenue bonds, with a maximum yield of 7.65 percent for an issue due in 2006, through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

headline: Trump Stores Report Denied
abstract: LEAD: Neither Donald J. Trump nor Alexander's Inc. has serious plans to convert any Alexander's department stores to luxury stores under the Trump name, Robin L. Farkas, chairman and chief executive of Alexander's, said yesterday.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Donna Campanella has joined Lintas: USA as senior vice president, group media planning director.

headline: Anchor Glass Sees Deficit in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Anchor Glass Container Corporation said that it expects net losses for the fourth quarter and full year. The company attributed the expected losses to the costs of production line changes in the second half, the effects of price discounting and smaller-than-expected shipments.

headline: Concern Expressed by Bush On Need to Reduce Deficits
abstract: LEAD: Responding to mounting concern about Federal budget deficits, President-elect Bush sought today to distance himself from economists who make light of the deficits and see little urgency in reducing them.

headline: Libyan Stand on Poison Gas
abstract: LEAD: A Libyan official told the Italian authorities Friday that his nation adhered to international rules that prohibit the use of chemical weapons but not their production, the Foreign Ministry said. The United States has said Libya is on the verge of producing chemical weapons. Maj. Abdul Salam Jalloud, considered No.

headline: Interco Raises Payouts And Rejects Higher Bid
abstract: LEAD: Interco Inc. today rejected as inadequate the Cardinal Acquisition Corporation's sweetened buyout offer and increased dividend payouts under a restructuring program.

headline: Food Makers Attacked In Ads on Cholesterol
abstract: LEAD: An Omaha manufacturing executive turned up the volume yesterday in his 22-year campaign against high cholesterol, which has been identified by nutritionists as a cause of heart attacks.

headline: For Kabul, It's Neutrality by Default
abstract: LEAD: The neutrality of Afghanistan, which President Najibullah has announced as one of his principal objectives, appears nearly at hand. Since the Soviet Union, without the Kabul Government, began top-level peace talks with the guerrilla leadership, the Afghan regime is so isolated that it appears to be no longer interfering even in its own international affairs.

headline: VISIT TO NEW YORK IS CUT A DAY SHORT
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev left New York for Moscow yesterday, cutting short a triumphant diplomatic mission to deal with the aftermath of an earthquake reported to have killed tens of thousands in Soviet Armenia.

headline: Farm Credit Bank Posts Bond Yields
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation is offering at a price of par a total of $2.46 billion in consolidated systemwide bonds with three-month, six-month, and one-year maturities through the corporation and various securities dealers and banks.

headline: Gallo Trial Over Name Is Completed
abstract: LEAD: A lawyer for Ernest and Julio Gallo contended today at the close of a monthlong trial in Federal District Court here that their younger brother took unfair and illegal advantage of their wine trademark by labeling his cheese with his name, ''Joseph Gallo.''

headline: Caution on Trade Offer
abstract: LEAD: The European Community gave a cautious response today to a United States offer to discuss short-term measures on world agriculture reform. A spokeswoman for the European Commission, acting for the European Community, said that, while the community welcomed any effort to undertake short-term reforms in agriculture, the American offer would have to be studied to ''see what the U.S.

headline: I.R.A. Blast at Army Housing
abstract: LEAD: A car bomb planted by the I.R.A. exploded at a British Army housing project today and an army spokesman said two people were treated for shock. The Irish Republican Army telephoned a warning about 30 minutes before the blast near the married soldiers' quarters in Lisburn, the army's Northern Ireland headquarters, about six miles south of Belfast.

headline: For Indians, Video Newsreels
abstract: LEAD: Indians, who often regard television news as little more than publicity for the Government, will soon have a choice of video news-documentary cassettes produced by irreverent, thorough and largely nonpartisan news magazines.

headline: New York Region Brushes Off Effect Of Oct. 19 Collapse
abstract: LEAD: A year after the stock-market collapse sent shock waves through the New York metropolitan region, economists and business executives say most job seekers have little cause for worry -their skills are in high demand.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * John W. Rindlaub, a senior vice president at Young & Rubicam, has been named director of corporate relations.

headline: Soviet Railway Blast Kills 4 and Injures 280
abstract: LEAD: Rail cars filled with explosives crashed into a coal train in the central Russian Republic today, causing an explosion that killed 4 people and injured 280, Soviet reports said.

headline: Hijacker Defends Achille Lauro Killing
abstract: LEAD: Abul Abbas, the Palestinian who planned the hijacking of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985, spoke publicly today about the incident, comparing the killing of an elderly American Jew aboard the ship to an automobile accident.

headline: Africans at the U.N. Express Skepticism on Pretoria Moves
abstract: LEAD: African foreign ministry officials warned today that a South African withdrawal from Namibia and renewed diplomatic contacts between South Africa and black African nations would not restore stability to southern Africa or improve Pretoria's standing on the continent.

headline: Dow Falls 9.24 on Economic Uncertainty
abstract: LEAD: The stock market sold off in relatively listless trading yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 9.24 points to close at 2,134.25.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds increased $2.6 billion, to $274.63 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 128 institutional funds increased $596.70 million, to $71.31 billion. Assets of the 224 general purpose funds were up $828.50 million, to $87.21 billion.

headline: Talks Reported on Baker Heading Drexel
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is discussing plans to have Howard H. Baker Jr. serve as its chairman after the expected indictment of the firm by Federal prosecutors, people familiar with the plan said.

headline: Onassis Child Gets Bulk of Estate
abstract: LEAD: The will of Christina Onassis, formally presented in an Athens court over the weekend, grants the vast bulk of her fortune to her 3-year-old daughter but provides a $1.5 million annuity to her fourth and last husband, from whom she was divorced in 1987.

headline: Copper Prices at Record Levels
abstract: LEAD: Copper traded at record levels yesterday as a two-week strike by Peruvian miners further tightened global supplies at a time of strong industrial demand for the metal worldwide.

headline: Quneitra Journal; A Blasted Place Where a Vengeful Spirit Thrives
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Khaled al-Natur, a Syrian Army officer, lowered his Soviet-made binoculars and gestured beyond his country's borders.

headline: Inventories Up by 0.7% In September
abstract: LEAD: Business inventories rose sharply relative to sales in September, a sign of economic weakness, but analysts discounted the significance of the increase, pointing out that sales have picked up since then.

headline: Iran, in Warning to OPEC, Threatens to Pump More Oil
abstract: LEAD: Iran stood firm today against pressure from the Arab nations in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and threatened to increase its oil production rather than agree to a smaller share of OPEC's production.

headline: Sprint Reduces Business Rates
abstract: LEAD: The U S Sprint Communications Company said Wednesday that it would reduce interstate rates for business products, including WATS and 800 services, by an average of 3.6 percent on Jan. 5.

headline: Talking Business; with Evangelist of Lend Lease Trucks; Truck Leasing: Growth Forecast
abstract: LEAD: After several years of consolidation, five companies now account for about 45 percent of the truck leasing market, and the trend shows no sign of abating. Lend Lease Trucks Inc. of Minneapolis and Whiteford Systems of South Bend, Ind., recently announced a merger agreement that will form the nation's fourth-largest truck leasing company.

headline: Holly Farms And Conagra Set Merger
abstract: LEAD: The Holly Farms Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest processor of fresh chicken, has agreed to merge with Conagra Inc., the second largest, in a stock deal valued at about $55 a share, or $957 million.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Boston Consulting Group, Boston, which is engaged in business strategy consulting, named as senior vice presidents Rudyard L. Istvan and Burkhard F. Wittek.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Debt

headline: SOUTH AFRICA JAILS A DRAFT RESISTER
abstract: LEAD: An 18-year-old pacifist from an affluent white Johannesburg suburb was sentenced today to six years in prison for refusing conscription into the South African Army.

headline: Choreography on a Stamping Line
abstract: LEAD: The changing of huge metal-forming dies at the General Motors Corporation's stamping plant here has been transformed from routine maintenance to industrial choreography, with each move by a 21-man team as carefully planned as a ballet company's.

headline: Decision in Securities Case Might Affect Drexel Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: In a decision that could have strong ramifications for the securities fraud action against Drexel Burnham Lambert, a Federal court yesterday dismissed an appeal by a defendant who had objected to the intervention of the United States Attorney in a Securities and Exchange Commission case.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: In Managua, 2 Economists Debate Crisis
abstract: LEAD: Of all the troubled economies in Latin America, none is plagued by so dazzling an array of ills as Nicaragua's.

headline: Rover to Add 850 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said today that its recently acquired auto manufacturing unit, Rover Group P.L.C., would create 850 more jobs at its Austin Rover division to meet increased demand. Last week, Austin Rover received a contract worth ;540 million, or about $945 million, from the car rental company Avis Europe P.L.C.

headline: 4% German Growth Seen
abstract: LEAD: The West German Economic Minister, Martin Bangemann, told Foreign Minister Sosuke Ono of Japan that he expected the German economy to grow by about 4 percent in real terms in 1988, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official said today. Mr. Bangemann was quoted as saying the West German economy was expanding steadily.

headline: Companies Search for Next $1 Billion Drug
abstract: LEAD: This year four pharmaceutical companies are expected to have drugs that each generate annual sales of a billion dollars or more. Such sales were unheard of just a few years ago, and the companies have a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to use their windfall profits to develop major new drugs.

headline: Whittaker Shares Increase by 8.3%
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the Whittaker Corporation rose $3.875, or 8.3 percent, to $50.625, on the New York Stock Exchange today, the day's eighth-largest percentage gainer. The Los Angeles-based specialty chemical and technology concern said it was considering expressions of takeover interest from third parties as well as other unspecified alternatives.

headline: Kiddie City Tests Discount Toys In Manhattan
abstract: LEAD: ''WE weren't sure what to expect,'' Marvin Katz was saying as he stood in Manhattan's new Kiddie City store next to a kangaroo bigger than him (there was nothing to worry about, since it was made out of Lego blocks). ''People wouldn't be coming in cars. They'd be riding the subways and buses. We decided not to stock many big items like bicycles.

headline: President Named Chief At Budget Rent-A-Car
abstract: LEAD: The Budget Rent-A-Car Corporation, the nation's No. 3 car rental company, yesterday named its president, Clifton E. Haley, to the additonal posts of chairman and chief executive.

headline: Pilots' Strike Curbs Alitalia
abstract: LEAD: Alitalia canceled 28 national and 6 international flights today because of a strike by pilots. The pilots said they would strike for two hours today, Thursday and Friday to protest lack of progress in talks between union representatives and the state-run airline.

headline: Shooting Attack Toll In Pretoria Reaches 6
abstract: LEAD: The death toll in a shooting attack on blacks in downtown Pretoria by a white neo-fascist rose to six today.

headline: Incidence of AIDS, High Now and Growing Fast, Alarms Central America
abstract: LEAD: The number of AIDS cases has reached alarming proportions in Central America, health officials in the region say, and the virus is continuing to spread rapidly throughout the area.

headline: State Dept. Excludes the Blind as Diplomats
abstract: LEAD: The State Department, after a decade of accepting Foreign Service job applications from blind people, has ruled that they are not suited to be American diplomats.

headline: 'SPOOKTACULAR' VIDEOS WITH DRACULA AND FREDDY
abstract: LEAD: Next weekend, employees of the National Video franchise in Appleton, Wis., will dress up in costume - for fun, but also to remind customers to buy or rent horror videotapes for Halloween. According to the assistant manager, Linda Gregorius, the 8,000-square-foot store stocks 7,500 titles. Twenty percent are in the horror or science fiction categories.

headline: Monthly Paper to Advise Nonprofit Groups
abstract: LEAD: Charities and other nonprofit organizations have traditionally looked to corporations and foundations to offer guidance on how to solicit funds. But The Nonprofit Times, a monthly four-color newspaper, hopes to change all that.

headline: N.A.S.D. Picks Chairman
abstract: LEAD: The board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers has elected William L. Tedford Jr., a vice president at Stephens Inc. of Little Rock, Ark., as chairman for 1989, the group said today. Mr. Tedford succeeds Stephen L. Hammerman, executive vice president, chief administrative officer and general counsel of Merrill Lynch & Company.

headline: Seoul Has Spoken, but Verdict on Chun Is Still Out
abstract: LEAD: Despite President Roh Tae Woo's appeal to South Koreans Saturday that they not ''skid into a deep quagmire of frustration,'' neither the political opposition nor the middle class seem prepared to end inquiries into the wrongdoings of former President Chun Doo Hwan anytime soon.

headline: Israeli and 8 Arabs Wounded
abstract: LEAD: Assailants with axes and knives attacked an Israeli businessman in the West Bank after Israeli forces raided three villages today and rounded up 20 Palestinians suspected of making bombs.

headline: PENTAGON IS URGED TO BE MORE ACTIVE IN ECONOMIC POLICY
abstract: LEAD: An independent advisory panel has urged the Secretary of Defense to take a more assertive role in setting economic policy to head off ''an increasing loss of technological leadership to both our allies and adversaries.''

headline: Kaufman Calls for Tax Rise
abstract: LEAD: The United States Government must soon raise taxes by up to $20 billion to avoid further drops in the value of the dollar and higher interest rates, a well-known Wall Street economist, Henry Kaufman, said today.

headline: Vehicle Output Rises
abstract: LEAD: Domestic auto makers were scheduled to produce 234,027 cars and light trucks this week, up from 233,484 last week, Ward's Automotive Reports said. This week's output is higher than the week a year earlier, in which 231,759 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said.

headline: U.S. Arm of Yugoslav Bank And 5 Accused of Laundering
abstract: LEAD: A Federal grand jury today indicted a Yugoslav Consul General, four other people and the American branch of a large Yugoslav bank on charges of participating in a money-laundering conspiracy. They were charged with conspiring to evade American cash-reporting laws through the use of Yugoslav diplomatic channels, among other techniques.

headline: For Trip to Courthouse, Just Basic Black Pumps
abstract: LEAD: Imelda Marcos stepped out of her darkened limousine into the autumn chill yesterday, wearing only a lightweight, bare-backed, floor-length, dazzling turquoise traditional Philippine dress that covered not only her ankles but also her footwear.

headline: No Pension Pinch
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: SPANISH PREMIER FACES STRIKE TEST
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez faces the biggest threat to his six-year-old Government on Wednesday, the prospect of the first general strike in Spain since 1934.

headline: LIBERALIZING STEPS PUSHED IN ALGERIA
abstract: LEAD: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria has taken his boldest move yet to liberalize the country's single-party rule by ousting the most influential hard-liner.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Marketing By Hospital Is a Success
abstract: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Americans spent almost $195 billion on hospital care last year, 9 percent more than in 1986, hospitals are finding themselves increasingly in the red. But Albert Einstein Medical Center in Philadelphia finished this fiscal year in the pink, thanks in part to a strong dose of marketing savvy administered by Robert B.

headline: Movement Is Seen in Southern Africa Talks
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that negotiations on the conflicts in Angola and Namibia were ''nearing success.''

headline: THE FED'S PLUMBER: E. Gerald Corrigan; A Crisis Manager Takes on the Mechanics of the Market
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the declines in stock prices reached alarming proportions last October, the first phone calls by bankers and securities dealers were to E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

headline: Pure 3-D Cover For Geographic
abstract: LEAD: The December issue of National Geographic will have an all-holographic cover.

headline: Prices of U.S. Issues Rise Moderately
abstract: LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices rose moderately in light trading yesterday, largely in response to a steadier dollar. But dealers in Government securities said much of the buying was done by those who had previously sold Treasury debt short.

headline: GAF Trial to Test U.S. Evidence in Insider Cases
abstract: LEAD: The GAF stock manipulation trial, which begins today with jury selection in Federal District Court in Manhattan,represents the first test of evidence that the Government has obtained from Boyd L. Jefferies.

headline: York Minster Is Back to Life After '84 Fire
abstract: LEAD: The south transept of York Minster, its 15th-century wooden arched ceiling and roof consumed by a fire four years ago, came back to life today.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Ex-Intelsat Official Jailed
abstract: LEAD: A former top executive of Intelsat was sentenced today to 16 months to 4 years in prison for his role in a $4.8 million kickback scheme involving construction of the satellite consortium's headquarters.

headline: Icahn Ending Attempt To Buy Eastern Airlines
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the investor and chairman of Trans World Airlines, told officials of the Texas Air Corporation yesterday that he was ending his effort to make a bid for Eastern Airlines.

headline: Pope Picks Conservative Cardinal for Cologne
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II put an end today to a 15-month struggle with West German clergymen by naming Joachim Cardinal Meisner, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Berlin and East Germany, to lead the Archdiocese of Cologne.

headline: USX Net Rises by 63%; Armco Posts 42% Gain
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation and Armco Inc. reported increased earnings yesterday.

headline: A HAITIAN PRIEST IS OUSTED BY ORDER
abstract: LEAD: A Roman Catholic priest who has been one of the most outspoken critics of social injustice in Haiti has been expelled from his ecclesiastic order and accused of using religion to incite hatred and violence.

headline: DEATH GANG LINKED TO PERU'S RULERS
abstract: LEAD: Extremists within Peru's ruling party are sponsoring a paramilitary group that has claimed credit for death threats, bombings and at least two murders over the past four months, according to well-placed Peruvian politicians.

headline: Market Place; Election Forecast For Investors
abstract: LEAD: A MONTH before the Presidential election, the markets and investors are pondering the impact of the outcome. There are all kinds of guides, from past performances to policies of the contenders. But that does not mean they have the answer.

headline: Turning Away Customers
abstract: LEAD: Czechoslovakia imposed stiff curbs and penalties on Christmas shoppers from Poland, East Germany, Hungary and the Soviet Union. Page D1.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN DIAMONDS; A Blaze of Gems for a Cold Winter's Night
abstract: LEAD: Diamonds are not only forever, they are also for Christmas. December is far and away the biggest month for diamond sales: in 1987, more than 40 percent of all diamonds were sold in December and about a quarter of all engagement rings are purchased for the holiday season. Why are diamonds so popular at Christmas?

headline: Death Sentences Given to 3 In Fatal Zimbabwe Bombing
abstract: LEAD: Three former members of the Rhodesian security forces were sentenced today to be hanged after being convicted on murder charges in a bomb attack on a house owned by the African National Congress.
